title: Who will be elected governor of Louisiana in the 2019 gubernatorial election?
preds:
Updating model [1] with latest PredictIt numbers. Model: 0%, 56%, 44%, 0%
Crowd: 1%, 53%, 46%, 0% [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE

Edwards, a relatively popular governor, has managed to peel off some Abraham voters from Rispone. https://www.ksla.com/2019/11/11/poll-louisiana-governors-race-tight-runoff-nears/ High African American turnout in early voting also benefits Edwards. https://www.theadvocate.com/baton_rouge/news/politics/elections/article_0477a39c-040e-11ea-9f9a-03cbe0cb6c3f.html

https://morningconsult.com/governor-rankings-q2-19/
https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/5267/Which-party-will-win-the-2019-Louisiana-gubernatorial-race
John Bel Edwards has a net approval rating of 21 percent in the most recent approval poll, which is admittedly a few months old.  However, he has consistently been 15 to 21 points net positive.  
The prediction markets are moving, ever so slightly, in his direction.   
The turnout in the 2018 midterm congressional election by democrats was almost exactly the same as it was in the 2016 general.  The same did not happy for republicans, who were down about 20 percent.  Normally, a 20 to 30 percent drop from presidential to mid-term elections is normal.  
The only down sides are that Edwards won four years ago largely to a prostitution scandal involving his  opponent, and he needs a very high turn out.
Election is getting closer and Edwards still has a substantial lead in polls.

Updating model [1] with latest PredictIt numbers. Model: 0%, 51%, 49%, 0%
Crowd: 1%, 44%, 54%, 1% [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE

Leaning a little more toward Rispone due to Trump's relatively high popularity in Louisiana. [1, 2] [1] https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-states-where-trump-is-more-and-less-popular-than-he-should-be/
[2] https://morningconsult.com/tracking-trump-2/
Increase percentage toward Edwards in light of Democrats good showing on November 5th.
This will be close, I think.

Updating model [1] with latest PredictIt numbers. Model: 0%, 36%, 64%, 0%
Crowd: 1%, 44%, 55%, 0% [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE
Just basing this on the election results on 10/12.

Updating model [1] with latest PredictIt numbers. Model: 0%, 31%, 69%, 0%
Crowd: 2%, 47%, 50%, 1% [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE

Edwards is the only Democratic governor in the Deep South and the only Democrat holding statewide office in Louisiana. Donald Trump won the state by 20 percentage points in 2016. The Republican Governors Association has described Louisiana as a top pickup opportunity, while the Democratic Governors Association has said Edwards’ popularity positions him for re-election. Of the five gubernatorial elections between 1999 and 2015, three were won outright in the primary and two (in 2003 and 2015) proceeded to general elections. Edwards was elected governor in 2015 with 56% of the vote, defeating U.S. Sen. David Vitter (R) in the general election. He succeeded Gov. Bobby Jindal (R).

The initial election of Edwards seems to have been a fluke in that his Republican opponent had a prostitution scandal.  Moreover, the total Republican votes in the general election exceeded Edward's votes.   However, Edwards is very popular.  Then again, so is Trump, and he is under impeachment.

Updating after primary results. Sources used:
https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/5267/Which-party-will-win-the-2019-Louisiana-gubernatorial-race
https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2019/governor/la/louisiana_governor_open_primary-6724.html

1.Edwards share of the vote dropped in 62 out of the 64 Parrishes in LA in this primary. 
2. Republicans won a super majority in the State Senate. 
3. Edwards's previous Republican opponent, David Vitter, was plagued by controversy.

Updating model [1] to account for Rispone coming in 2nd after Edwards and the two facing off in a runoff [2] next month. Model now is purely matching PredictIt now that only one from each party. Model: 0%, 43%, 57%, 0%
Crowd: 9%, 71%, 17%, 3% [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE
[2] https://www.politico.com/news/2019/10/12/democrat-edwards-will-face-runoff-in-louisiana-governors-race-000285
Edwards and Rispone advance to runoff election. https://www.politico.com/news/2019/10/12/democrat-edwards-will-face-runoff-in-louisiana-governors-race-000285

Revising the probability of Edwards victory down given that Edwards has been forced into a run-off with Rispone. https://www.politico.com/news/2019/10/12/democrat-edwards-will-face-runoff-in-louisiana-governors-race-000285

Despite it's being a reliably red state, louisiana does have a history of choosing democratic governors.  With the reubliKKKans being as embattled as they are on the national stage, I believe the state will stick with its incumbent democrat for now.
Slightly revising the probability of an Edwards (D) win upwards given recent polling.
Despite attack ads on Edwards he has been good for Louisiana and his two competitors just don't appear to have the necessary qualification.

Updating model [1] with current PredictIt; GOP candidate forecast component updated with latest September polls. Model: 14%, 70%, 16%, 0%
Crowd: 22%, 69%, 7%, 2% [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE

Revising ahead of tonight's debate. Two metrics (party and incumbent history) are now weighted 80% and 20% respectively and arranged as 1st and 2nd degrees, with available points for each degree divided between candidates based on personal opinion, though would like to see this influenced in the future by other metrics. Trying to understand the threat of lesser candidates to pulling votes from majors. For example, if Dantzler pulls about 12% of democrat vote, he could prevent Edwards from taking all in jungle.

Purely based on a 13 election history (going back to first time incumbent allowed to run for re-election as LA governor) of two factors weighted equally: party election and incumbent re-election vs. challenger. The history is weighted so that elections decrease in value as their age increases. Interesting and a rough baseline. Probably too much given to 'None' and not enough to two named R candidates.  The party history is very close, though dems have roughly a 2 point lead there. Incumbents have a good history of re-election (~36 pt lead), but this does not take into consideration party affiliation of incumbent (which may or may not be important). I have a third factor of party staying power (chance of party to maintain control of office), but it severely underrates party in control when weighted equally with other factors. It should probably be rolled into one of the other two.  Disclaimer: I am a Louisiana resident planning to vote. This is my very first forecast on GJO, and would like to extend this model to the other two gubernatorial races happening concurrently. I haven't looked at individual factors for each candidate such as sponsors, campaign budget, political office history, etc. Things I believe are interesting that I'd like to incorporate in the future.
Correcting previous. I had mixed up Rispone and Abraham.
Edwards ahead but not far. Rispone seems only viable alternative.  Allowing for outside possibilities with Abraham.

Using @dglid's model, but based on [1], 13 governors have gone for reelection, 8 won and 5 lost putting the outside view base rate at 62% for Edwards to win, which is pretty close to the current forecast.  https://www.businessreport.com/newsletters/lapolitics-governors-race-by-the-numbers

Updating model [1] with current PredictIt; GOP candidate forecast component updated with latest September polls. Crowd: 23%, 66%, 8%, 3% [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE

Rispone seems like an unlikely contender. The polls give Edwards the edge, plus he is the incumbant. However, the jungle election format could toss Rispone's voters to the other Republican candidate, so Abraham has a solid chance.
 I used Wikipedia for my main source of info: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Louisiana_gubernatorial_election

Updating model [1] with current PredictIt. Also using last two polls as listed in Wikipedia instead of latest shown on RCP, since Wikipedia has more recent polls (thanks for the tip @ccorcoran223). Crowd: 24%, 74%, 2%, 0% [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE

John Bel Edwards is clear leader of the race but has some disadvantages of not having house and Senate majority. He doesn't have as many negative scandals as other two. Eddie has nothing attractive to let him move forward and may step down sooner than expected.
Edwards has the incumbency advantage and is generally liked (his numbers aren't great but he is above water) so I think he gets under 50% in the primary and then wins in the run-off.

As the question is stated with 2 Republicans and 1 Democrat, the Republican vote would be split while the Democrats have a solid support base. Combine that with the incumbent advantage, at this point in time it looks to be a Democrat victory. However if Republicans could mount one candidate instead of two, this forecast would be completely different. As the race gets closer, I will do an updated forecast.
As for Q on Kentucky's gubernatorial election, I agree with the modelling results of @dglid

I am aggregating polls and prediction market odds for now [1,2] [1] https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/5267/Which-party-will-win-the-2019-Louisiana-gubernatorial-race
[2] https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2019/governor/la/louisiana_governor_open_primary-6724.html

Simple model [1] using implied probability from PredictIt [2] for likelihood of Dem win, then dividing GOP candidate probabilities based on latest poll from RCP [3]. Latest poll is from April, so might be missing something here, but happy enough with this for now. [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1000030620
[2] https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/5267/Which-party-will-win-the-2019-Louisiana-gubernatorial-race
[3] https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2019/governor/la/louisiana_governor_open_primary-6724.html

This could be a two part election, the first on 12 October and if no candidate gets an absolute majority then a run off in November.  Edwards (Dem) is the incumbent, and has been leading in the polls constantly over both GOP candidates. When all three are included, Edwards comes ahead of Abraham, followed by Rispone. As the election requires only an absolute majority, if the GOP vote is split between the two candidates, then we will get a run off as happened in 2015. The GOP has won 4 of 7 of the gubernatorial elections since 1992, but this will be the first time that a Dem has run for reelection (96 Edwin Edwards didnt run, 2008 Kathleen Blano didnt run again). Both the republicans who ran for a second term were elected.  In this election, I expect the GOP vote to split, with Edwards winning but not with an absolute majority and then a run off which the incumbent Governor will win vs Abraham. Will update with polls, scandals, etc.
